audio_caption: The clip begins with someone starting a presentation, introducing a topic about "filecoin and AI". The speaker describes filecoin as a network for storing data and suggests the data can be used for machine learning if it is properly harvested. The speaker is male and presents the information with a clear and informative speaking tone. Throughout the clip, there is background speech suggesting a conference or similar environment, with people talking amongst themselves.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing the democratization of AI and regulatory policies. His tone is informative. Intermittent crowd noise and indistinct speech create a background ambiance.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing Filecoin, highlighting its role as a provenance layer and immutability. Next, he speaks about storage providers worldwide, suitable for data locality policies and machine learning needs. Then, he is going to talk about the data architecture is changing. The background contains sounds resembling speech and subtle audio artifacts.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing traditional banking practices, including OLTP transactions, data warehousing, and data lakes. He describes the evolution of data storage and usage in enterprises, noting the shift from structured data to incorporating unstructured data from sources like social media. The speaker mentions JSON formats and the creation of data lakes, as well as the transformation of data into data marts and dashboards. He emphasizes that this was the approach before the rise of AI and LM popularity.

A male speaker begins, speaking in a neutral tone about the prevalence of data lakes in enterprises and how they aggregate structured and unstructured data. He mentions that a lot of data is put into the data plane, and data scientists are now applying machine learning on top of it. He notes that this is slightly different now, and that the machine learning training portion, specifically the feature store, is something relatively new.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who describes how feature stores can share features across organizations. He then highlights a use case of Filecoin, emphasizing that its features, used for training, are stored within the network, making them immutable. This immutability allows proof that no features were altered during the machine learning process, ensuring audits and policy checks show compliance. The speaker maintains a clear and informative tone throughout the explanation.

A male speaker with an even tone discusses how decentralization led to the realization that aggregating everything into a data lake is too difficult. He cites a $30 million project in Southeast Asia where banks, after significant investment and time, discovered that consumers lacked the domain knowledge to utilize the data lake. As a result, he notes the shift towards moving data to business units and domain experts within the organization.

The clip begins with a male speaker, who talks about creating data products and data contracts that can be used in an "FVM context" and a "perpetual data deal". He mentions needing "fresh new data" to retrain a machine learning model. There are footsteps in the background throughout his speech, suggesting he may be walking while speaking.

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing "the data mesh." He describes a business unit and states he will skip a part. Later, he explains that storage providers have a FEM within an ecosystem, powering a "customer 360 use case." He uses an example of buying a car to illustrate how marketing profiles can be aggregated and used to train a recommendation model. Then he mentions that the Filecoin network can sell data to create complex or more complete use cases. Throughout, the male speaker speaks in a clear, explanatory tone. In the background, a distinct, sharp sound effect of a marker on a whiteboard is consistently heard.

The clip starts with one male speaker introducing ecosystem wins and specifically mentioning a partner called Bitdeer. He says that Bitdeer created a GPU cloud and the data will be stored on filecoin. The speaker continues describing how they're creating a pipeline to ensure most data flows into filecoin, that way it can create an audit trail for immutability. He notes their global reach with data centers in Singapore and the US, and expansion plans to more countries, emphasizing that they are an NVIDIA preferred partner, and shared filecoin at an NVIDIA GTC event. He highlights an image showcasing filecoin and informs the audience that he will be showcasing this picture to further understand what this partner is doing behind the scenes on the GPU cloud.

The audio begins with speech discussing "bitcoin mining" and quickly transitions to a description of an interface, mentioning "model training" and a "model playground" where users can train and upload models to "BitDiers Cloud." This speaker notes the ability to share models and points out a "model marketplace" similar to "Hugging Face." The speaker observes they are currently not charging for model consumption. Throughout the entire clip, background speech is present, creating an ambient buzz of conversation.

The audio begins with a male speaker explaining how FVM, Filecoin, and IPFS can be used to create smart contracts and AI, facilitating perpetual deals with various entities and leveraging machine learning platforms for data management. He suggests using smart contracts for enforcement across different data sources. Transitioning to decentralized data and LM, he mentions their role as a Filecoin storage provider, hosting data on their network and seeking collaboration with other storage providers. The speaker invites listeners to reach out with use case ideas. The background remains relatively quiet, allowing focus on the speaker.

A male speaker discusses governance, emphasizing that storing steps of the machine learning lifecycle onto Falco creates an audit trail and metadata trail to enforce auditability. He then transitions to the machine learning lifecycle, indicating he will briefly discuss it, his tone informative and focused.
A single male speaker discusses feature engineering and model development, mentioning "data provenance layer" for audit trails and archiving predictions. The speaker maintains a conversational tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker, likely presenting or concluding a speech, inviting audience members with AI projects to connect with him for potential advertisement or advice on integration. His tone is professional and encouraging. Following his statement, the clip concludes with audience applause, indicating the end of his presentation.
